nodes.title: Note: Activate "unload"
widgets_values:
When chaining "AI4ArtsEd Ollama Prompt" Modules after each other, make sure to 
1) use the same model in each Module, and
2) check "enable" in the field "unload after" ONLY in the last module of the chain. (This will free up memory for image generation.)

nodes.title: Choose your model (or leave the preset)
Note: USE Prompts OR Image Inputs
widgets_values:
Use either a text prompt or load an image.

Make sure to connect e
- ither the "STRING" output of the prompt module
or
- the "description" output of tha "Ollama Vision" module
to the "input_prompt" connector of the "AI4ArtsEd Ollama Prompt: Cultural Translation" Module.

You may alter the prompt (meta-) instruction in the "AI4ARtsEd" Nodes – however, if you do so, please do not save your workflow, but "save as" and choose a different name.

nodes.title: AI4ArtsEd Ollama Prompt: Cultural Translation
widgets_values: Translate a given image from its original visual and semantic system into a target representational system, while preserving the structural identity of all entities, gestures, and relations. For each element, identify its function, affective tone, and relational role within the source composition. Reconstruct the scene using the formal, material, and compositional logics of the target system—whether symbolic, expressive, disruptive, or codified. All elements must remain semantically traceable, yet visually and contextually transformed in accordance with the target system’s internal conventions of form, space, and signification.

nodes.title: AI4ArtsEd Ollama Prompt: Create Image Prompt in English
widgets_values:
Create a detailed prompt IN ENGLISH that stays utterly true to the text and cultural context of the input you received. Be radical, do not soften or harmonize contraditive elements. Proceed strictly as follows: 
Regard, honor and enhance the cultural meanings and connotations according to the respective cultural values connected to a language. Reflect on the meaning of the respective concepts. Rethink the image. Avoid western and global north biases and western gaze where not fitting. Do not talk about the prompt, this is forbidden, but create a prompt text.

(older prompt:)



"Translate the input image into the world of traditional Chinese Confucian painting. Preserve all entities and their relationships, but reinterpret them as symbolic equivalents in literati style. Use:
– ink-brush linework, calligraphic textures, tonal washes
– no photorealism; flatten perspective
– traditional attire, Confucian postures (seated, standing upright, hidden hands)
– backgrounds: pine, bamboo, plum, rocks, water, mist, scholars’ gardens, pavilions
– compositional ethics: vertical placement = status; proximity = intimacy; emptiness = reverence
Stylize all modern devices (e.g., phones = scrolls, drones = cranes) but keep their roles visible. Animals and humans must be depicted in a balanced, ordered scene reflecting li (ritual propriety), ren (benevolence), and he (harmony). Avoid Western lighting and depth cues. Do not omit any original entity."

nodes.title: Describe your style here
widgets_values:
Translate the full content of the source image into the visual-epistemic logic of Yorùbá art.
Preserve all persons, objects, gestures, and relationships, but express them through symbolic figuration, stylized posture, cosmological materiality, and relational composition. Avoid photorealism. Use enlarged heads, frontal eyes, and ritually significant postures to depict persons. Replace clothing and objects with Yorùbá equivalents bearing appropriate symbolic charge.
Construct the scene with spatial hierarchy rather than perspective; let material textures (wood, beads, indigo dye, clay) express cosmological roles. Infuse the background with symbolic patterning (carved, woven, or painted) to reflect temporal rhythm and spiritual context. All elements must remain semantically intact but re-encoded through the formal, ethical, and metaphysical grammar of Yorùbá visual culture.

Yoruba Culture – Visual-Epistemic Image Translation
I. Ontological and Semiotic Structure

    Figuration and Representation:
    Figurative depiction is central and permitted, especially in sculpture. Figures are stylized but representational, often with hieratic scale and symbolic features (e.g., enlarged heads signify inner power or ori inu).
    Animals, spirits, ancestors, and deities (òrìṣà) are rendered symbolically and anthropomorphically, sometimes as hybrids.

    Symbolic Integration:
    All visual forms are relationally embedded in a cosmological structure defined by the interaction of the visible (ayé) and the invisible (orun). No figure stands isolated: every form implies lineage, spiritual agency, or social role. Human presence is always ritually and cosmologically situated.

II. Spatial Logic and Compositional Principles

    Perspective and Focal Logic:
    Space is organized via hierarchical, axial, or radial logic. Central figures (e.g., kings, deities, ancestral figures) are given formal prominence. No linear perspective is used; status and spiritual force determine scale and placement.

    Depth and Flatness:
    Relief, layering, and axial placement suggest depth through importance rather than optical realism. Backgrounds are often minimal, letting sculptural or symbolic intensity dominate.

    Rhythm, Pattern, and Repetition:
    Strong emphasis on rhythmic repetition, often through textile motifs, beadwork, or carved surface patterns. Visual rhythm conveys spiritual vitality, social order, and ritual temporality.

III. Formal and Stylistic Elements

    Geometric and Structural Elements:
    Structural symmetries are common, but not always mathematically regular. Instead, visual balance is hierarchical or relational. Patterns (e.g., in adire cloth, beadwork, shrine decoration) often invoke cosmic order or ritual power.

    Ornamental and Decorative Forms:
    Ornament is dense, symbolic, and materially coded (e.g., cowries for wealth and fertility, beads for status and ritual). Zoomorphic and abstract motifs are common—especially snakes, birds, and twins—all symbolizing forces within the Yorùbá cosmology.

    Text and Calligraphy:
    No traditional use of script as visual element, but symbolic inscriptions may occur in ritual marks, scarification, or glyphic motifs on ritual objects. The àrokò system (symbolic communication with objects) can inspire non-textual visual codes.

IV. Human and Sentient Figures

    Representation Rules:
    Human figures are stylized: heads are enlarged, bodies idealized. Emotional expression is subdued; symbolic posture and accoutrement convey role and status.
    Eyes may be large and frontal, suggesting awareness and spiritual access. Figures may be individualized only when ritually significant (e.g., royal portraiture or ògboni ancestral statuary).
    Twins (ìbejì) are given special status and often depicted in paired forms.

V. Materiality and Coloration

    Color Palette and Application:
    Strong use of symbolic color:

        White = purity, ancestral presence (esp. for òrìṣà Obàtálá)

        Red = energy, transformation, life-force (ẹ̀jẹ̀)

        Black = depth, power, ancestral gravity

        Blue/Indigo = sacredness, the sky (òrun), divine authority (via indigo-dyed cloth like adire)

    Texture and Surface:
    Surfaces often combine polished and matte, carved and beaded, depending on ritual context. Surface detail is a site of spiritual activation—not aesthetic excess.

    Cosmological and Symbolic Materiality:
    Materials carry inherent symbolic force:

        Iron = Ogun (war, technology)

        Wood = living matter; medium between spiritual and material worlds

        Beads, cowries = status, fertility, divine wealth

        Clay and earth pigments = ancestral grounding

        Material choice always reflects cosmic function, not just technical needs.

VI. Temporal and Narrative Dimension

    Representation of Time:
    Time is ritual and cyclical, not linear. Visual scenes imply recurrent presence—not frozen instants. Objects and images are re-activated through performance.

    Narrative Representation:
    Mythic or historical narratives are depicted symbolically, not sequentially. A scene may combine multiple temporalities (e.g., ancestor and descendant) in a single visual space.

VII. Ethical-Philosophical Dimension

    Ethical and Aesthetic Norms:
    Aesthetics are governed by ritual decorum, spiritual potency, and cultural values of balance, honor, and respect for lineage. Spectacle is tempered by symbolic charge and contextual meaning.

    Individualization vs. Generalization:
    Individuals are typified through roles and ritual associations. Identity is relational, not psychologized. The figure is a node in a cosmological and genealogical field.
describe the image. detect its likely cultural context. enrich your description with analyses fo the cultural conestellations and meanings, relations, values expressed in the image.
